title: New California plastics law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom | CNN
body: CNN —. In an attempt to slash the wide-ranging impacts of plastic pollution, California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed into law the country's most sweeping restrictions on single-use plastics and ...
readable_content: - CNN (2023-12-08): In an effort to combat plastic pollution, California has implemented new laws to phase out single-use plastics and packaging. The law mandates that single-use packaging and plastic single-use food serviceware be recyclable or compostable by 2032, requires a 25% reduction in the sales of plastic packaging, and sets a goal for 65% of all single-use plastic packaging to be recycled by 2032. Additionally, it establishes an accountability group to manage a new recycling program. The law also requires plastic producers to pay $500 million annually for 10 years into the California Plastic Pollution Mitigation Fund. Critics within the plastics industry voiced disappointment, while environmental advocates view the law as a significant step in reducing plastic waste.
summary: The implementation of new laws in California aimed at phasing out single-use plastics and packaging has sparked mixed reactions. Critics within the plastics industry have expressed disappointment, while environmental advocates view the law as a significant step in reducing plastic waste. Overall, the sentiment is mixed.
